cip.render.raytrace

Class RayIntersection

  • java.lang.Object
    • cip.render.raytrace.RayIntersection

  • public class RayIntersection
extends java.lang.Object
    This is the description of the surface at the intersection of a ray with a geometric object. Because ray intersections are frequently used temporary objects that contain a description of the complete intersection tree beneath them they are also a good place to hold the object cache for temporary geometric objects they use in the computation of the intersection tree.

    The RayIntersection maintains a non-thread-safe object cache. If a given RayIntersection is only accessed by a single thread, then the object cache maintained by that intersection may be used to borrow/return objects of most 3d utility types with no synchronization overhead. This is useful in the context of either a single or multi-threading because the new operator is thread-safe which imposes high synchronization overhead, and garbage collecting when the object goes out-of-scope also imposes high overhead. In tests, the local cache is substantially faster than either a global cache or new operator. The performance of a local cache scales as would be expected with multiple threads on a multi-processor environment, while global cache and new implementations may actually slow operation when multiple threads are started on a multi-processor machine, presumably because of synchronization collisions and subsequent blocking.

    Since:
    1.0

    • Field Detail

      • m_fDist

        public float m_fDist
        The distance from the ray origin to the intersection .

      • m_fSampleSolidAngle

        public float m_fSampleSolidAngle
        The solid angle of the sample. This is the solid angles as seen from the effective start of the sampling ray and can be used to compute the area represented by the intersection sample. The solid angle is measured from the true start of the ray which is typically the eye. The cross-sectional area of the sample (area perpendicular to the view vector) at the sample is equal to m_fSampleSolidAngle * ((m_fDist + m_fSampleStartOffset) ^ 2) . When the ray starts at the eye, m_fSampleStartOffset = 0.0. This offset is used to account for this intersection being for a refracted or reflected ray that is continuing to spread along some solid angle from the location where it originally started. This will be 0.0 if it has not been set (for backwards compatibility).

      • m_fSampleStartOffset

        public float m_fSampleStartOffset
        The distance to add to m_fDist to get the effective distance from the start of the sample to which the solid angle applies. For example, if a ray from the eye is reflected from a plane, the reflected ray continues with the same solid angle as the ray from the eye and (m_fDist + m_fSampleStartOffset) is the cumulative distance the ray has traveled. In a really good implementation, the curvature of the surface is considered which may either spread of focus the solid angle after reflection and/or refraction. NOTE: if m_fSampleStartOffset = Float.POSITIVE_INFINITY it means this is a parallel projection and m_fSampleSolidAngle is the actual cross-sectional area of the sample.

      • m_pt

        public Point3f m_pt
        The point at which the ray intersects the surface

      • m_vNormal

        public Vector3f m_vNormal
        The normal of the surface at the intersection point

      • m_vToEye

        public Vector3f m_vToEye
        The direction vector from the surface intersection to the eye (ray origin). NOTE: ray origin = m_pt + m_fDist(m_vToEye). Also note that the vector is technically the vector back to where the intersection was computed from, which may be the eye, but may also be any other point it space such as a reflective or transparent surface which is spawning the recursive reflection and refraction rays, or, testing for visibility from a light source.

      • m_ptObject

        public Point3f m_ptObject
        The object space location of the intersection

      • m_vObjNormal

        public Vector3f m_vObjNormal
        The object space normal of the intersection

        The object space normal of the intersection

      • m_vTexture

        public Vector3f[] m_vTexture

      • m_mtl

        public IRtMaterial m_mtl
        The material of the surface at the ray intersection

      • m_rtObj

        public IRtGeometry m_rtObj
        The geometry intersected by the ray

      • m_fMaxContribution

        public float m_fMaxContribution
        The maximum contribution this intersection can make to the final colour at a pixel. This value is normalized to the range 0 to 1. When an intersection is queried for colour, the first query carries a contribution of 1. As rays are subsequently spawned from the intersection, the color contributed by those rays decreases based on the surface properties where the rays were spawned.

      • RayIntersection

        public RayIntersection()
        Creates a new uninitialized instance of RayIntersection

    • Method Detail

      • initialize

        public RayIntersection initialize(Vector3f vFromEye)
        Initialize a RayIntersection for the start of intersection testing. This sets the view vector for the intersection, sets the distance to the maximum representable distance in single precision, and nulls the object and material references.
        Parameters:
        vFromEye - The normalized direction vector for the ray being tested. The reverse of this will be set as the V vector leaving the intersection.
        Returns:
        Returns this RayIntersection.

      • setValue

        public RayIntersection setValue(RayIntersection intInit)

      • borrowIntersection

        public RayIntersection borrowIntersection()
        Borrow a ray intersection object. The borrowed ray intersection object should be returned to the RayIntersection from which it was borrowed. This function is not thread-safe.
        Returns:
        Returns an un-initialized ray intersection object.

      • returnIntersection

        public void returnIntersection(RayIntersection intersection)
        Returns a borrowed ray intersection object. This function is not thread-safe.
        Parameters:
        intersection - The ray intersection object being returned.
